intro: Xiphopteris zurquina, commonly known as the Zürquina huperzia, is a species of clubmoss native to the tropical regions of South America. It is characterized by its compact, evergreen foliage and a rosette-like growth habit. The plant features dark green, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a waxy cuticle, which helps reduce water loss in its humid environment. Xiphopteris zurquina typically grows in shaded, moist forest understories, where it thrives in nutrient-rich, well-drained soils. Its reproductive structures, known as sporangia, are clustered on the underside of the leaves, contributing to its role in spore dispersal.
